The answer is different in different societies. In my country, Australia, State governments fund schools, not local governments. Both “Public” and “Private” (usually religious) schools get funding from the State. Hence location is not as important as it is in the USA. Most private primary schools (ages 5 - 11) are religious, and some parents choose that path. Families that are not well off cannot support their children as well as richer families do, but provided the children can attend school they will get access to the facilities needed.
The more wealthy and secular your social group is, the more education becomes about choice, and learning how to choose. Asking ‘why’, and then discovering the answer.
